awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Injury Science Research Experiences for Undergraduates
awd_abstract_narration:
The Injury Science Research Experiences for Undergraduates Site at The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP), Center for Injury Research and Prevention (CIRP), provides a personalized internship experience to a diverse pool of talented interns with the aim of inspiring the pursuit of careers in science, technology, and engineering. The ten week summer program engages undergraduate students in foundational research experiences, one-on-one faculty mentorship, workshops, meetings, and field trips at CIRP. The program serves to provide women and underrepresented interns and those from STEM-limited programs with inspiration to pursue advanced science or engineering degrees, increase knowledge and interest in science and engineering, gain professional development, develop the ability to solve real-world problems, and prepare to optimize technology for safety solutions through user-centered, participatory design and human factors research. This program is active at a time when the country and world are on the brink of safety transformations enabled by technology, making the imperative for our training all the more critical for our country. Injuries and violence remain the leading causes of death and acquired disability for children, youth and young adults in the United States and worldwide, and remains the CIRP REU intellectual focus. This work supports the UN and World Health Assembly resolution on child injury prevention that highlighted an urgent, unfilled need for child-specific injury prevention research and people trained to meet this challenge.

The Injury Science REU Site goals for its interns include: 1) provide foundational research experiences that inspire women and underrepresented interns and those from STEM-limited programs to pursue advanced engineering degrees, 2) increase knowledge and interest in engineering and science 3) increase knowledge and interest in injury science/engineering 4) provide professional development 5) develop ability to solve real-world problems, and 6) prepare to optimize technology for safety solutions through user-centered, participatory design and human factors research. The program's in-discipline mentorship is complemented by an interdisciplinary exposure to give the interns the broad perspective in human subjects research, ethics, human factors, user-centered design, community-based participatory research, data science and entrepreneurship. Interns participate in traditional discipline-specific, lab-based training (intellectual foundation research) while also gaining the real-world exposure needed to deeply understand injury problems in order to create widely adopted, impactful solutions (translational research). They also learn industry/university partnership methods by working alongside entrepreneurs, industry, government and healthcare as well as with youth, families and their communities (broader impacts research).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Injuries and violence remain the leading causes of death and acquired disability for children, youth, and young adults in the US and worldwide.  Addressing this global health challenge requires providing the next generation of scientists and engineers with the scientific foundation, technical skills, research training, and entrepreneurial skills necessary to conduct impactful research and fuel innovation in field of injury science.  However, as noted by the National Academies, a dearth of funding for research training in injury prevention remains a major barrier to the development of this field.  Therefore, the Injury Science Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site aims to overcome this barrier by assisting the nation in developing diverse, internationally competitive, and globally-engaged leaders of science and engineering with a focus on pediatric injury prevention.

For over two decades, the world-renowned Center for Injury Research and Prevention (CIRP), a Center of Emphasis at The Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) Research Institute, has provided a unique research and training site for the next generation of scientists and engineers who, through rigorous scholarship, address the leading risk of injuries to children, youth, and young adults: concussion, traffic crashes, and violence.  Since 2011, CIRP has been honored to include as part of its training program the National Science Foundation Injury Science REU Site.  CIRP recently completed its Injury Science REU Site renewal period from September 2018 through August 2022.  During this renewal period, the Injury Science REU Site provided research training in the form of four 10-week summer internships for 42 undergraduates, 34 of which were funded through this NSF REU award; an additional 8 undergraduates were funded by supplemental grants and programs from CIRP-affiliated organizations.

REU interns received one-on-one research mentorship from internationally-accomplished research faculty at The Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, University of Pennsylvania, and Drexel University.  To foster scholarly independence, REU interns along with their faculty mentors identified an independent research question to pursue during their tenure.  Research topics included (1) examining child occupant motion during pre-crash maneuvers and take-over reaction time in critical autonomous driving scenarios, (2) advancing novel technological interventions for motor rehabilitation in children, (3) combining advanced simulated driving tools with state-of-the-art neuroimaging techniques to reveal the underlying cognitive and neural mechanisms of driving behavior and crash incidence, and (4) using animal models to identify altered brain circuitry that underlie and contribute to cognitive impairment caused by mild traumatic brain injury.

Interns also participated in the Injury Science REU Site Research Curriculum.  This curriculum consisted of seminars, workshops, laboratory tours, and networking social events designed to (1) exposure the REU interns to various research topics and state-of-the-art research facilities, (2) develop leadership, public speaking, and other professional skills, and (3) build their professional network.  Interns also received mentorship from CIRP graduate students, including guidance on applying to graduate school and hosting an entirely student-run journal club.  The Injury Science REU program culminated with CIRP’s Annual Student Research Day, at which students presented their work to the larger CHOP Research Institute. 

Despite the challenges brought forth by the COVID-19 pandemic, the Injury Science REU Site remained devoted to its trainees.  During the Summer of 2020, REU Site directors and faculty mentors rapidly transformed our REU site into a fully virtual educational program, consisting of interactive workshops, seminars, and journal clubs.  Our REU Site was again reformatted in 2021 to create our first hybrid program, consisting of both fully-remote and in-person trainees.  Despite these necessary deviations from our traditional in-person program, our REU Site’s evaluation methods (intern surveys, focus groups, and essays describing achievements) continued to show substantial programmatic success, with our interns meeting or exceeding all long and short-term measurable goals.  Specifically, all interns exhibited knowledge gains and increased interest in pursuing graduate education and research and/or pediatric injury science careers, demonstrating the ability of our program to successfully provide research training for fully-remote trainees.  While our program returned to a fully in-person training experience in 2022, the lessons learned from the COVID-19 pandemic will allow the Injury Science REU Site to offer such remote options, should a future need arise.  

Our programmatic evaluation results are supported by the accomplishments of Injury Science REU alumni.  Twelve (29%) of REU interns remained working on their research project after completion of the internships, culminating in 2 peer-reviewed manuscripts and 6 conference presentations involving Injury Science REU interns as authors to-date.  Alumni of the Injury Science REU Site have also gone on to pursue graduate degrees and research careers.  Of our 32 REU interns who have since graduated from their undergraduate institutions, 31% are in or have completed graduate programs and 63% are employed in STEM careers.  Four alumni returned to CHOP or one of its affiliated universities to pursue a graduate degree or additional research training.
